awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Refining glacial lake history in Taylor Valley, East Antarctica with alternative geochronometers
awd_abstract_narration:
Correlating ecosystem responses to past climate forcing is highly dependent on the use of reliable techniques for establishing the age of events (dating techniques). In Antarctic dry regions (land areas without glaciers), carbon-14 dating has been used to assess the ages of organic deposits left behind by ancient lakes. However, the reliability of the ages is debatable because of possible contamination with "old carbon" from the surrounding landscape. The proposed research will attempt to establish two alternate dating techniques, in situ carbon-14 cosmogenic radionuclide exposure dating and optically stimulated luminescence (OSL), as reliable alternate dating methods for lake history in Antarctic dry areas that are not contaminated by the old carbon. The end goal will be to increase scientific understanding of lake level fluctuation in the lakes of Taylor Valley, Antarctica so that inference about past climate, glacier, and ecosystem response can be inferred. The results of this study will provide a coarse-scale absolute chronology for lake level history in Taylor Valley, demonstrate that exposure dating and OSL are effective means to understand the physical dynamics of ancient water bodies, and increase the current understanding of polar lacustrine and ice sheet responses to past and present climatic changes. These chronologies will allow polar lake level fluctuations to be correlated with past changes in global and regional climate, providing information critical for understanding and modeling the physical responses of these environments to modern change. This research supports a PhD student; the student will highlight this work with grade school classes in the United States.

This research aims to establish in situ carbon-14 exposure dating and OSL as reliable alternate (to carbon-14 of organic lake deposits) geochronometers that can be used to settle the long-disputed lacustrine history and chronology of Taylor Valley, Antarctica and elsewhere. Improved lake level history will have significant impacts for the McMurdo Dry Valleys Long Term Ecological Research (MCM LTER) site as the legacy of fluctuating lake levels of the past affects the distribution of organic matter and nutrients, and impacts biological connectivity valley-wide. This work will provide insight into the carbon reservoir of large glacial lakes in the late Holocene and have implications for previously reported radiocarbon chronologies. OSL samples will be analyzed in the Desert Research Institute Luminescence Laboratory in Reno, NV. For the in situ carbon-14 work, rock samples extracted from boulders and bedrock surfaces will be prepared at Tulane University. The prepared in situ carbon-14 samples will be analyzed at the National Ocean Sciences Accelerator Mass Spectrometry laboratory in Woods Hole, MA. The two datasets will be combined to produce a reliable, coarse scale chronology for late Quaternary lake level fluctuations in Taylor Valley.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project employed a novel method for dating historic lake level changes in lower Taylor Valley, an Antarctic dry valley along the southern Victoria Land coast. The lake levels in lower Taylor Valley fluctuate in response to the hydrologic balance of the region and to changes in the size of the lake basin. Dating past lake levels can therefore lead to a better understanding of both the climatic history of this region and the timing of local alpine glacier and ice sheet advance and retreat. Changes in lake area associated with lake level changes affected historic habitat distribution and hydrologic connectivity in Taylor Valley, which affects the modern distribution of legacy soil nutrients. In addition, these lake level driven lake area changes would have caused changes in local depositional systems, leading to permanent changes in the valley’s morphology. 

In polar deserts such as Taylor Valley, datable organic materials that are more commonly used for dating deposits from the recent past (i.e. ~60 ka to present) are limited. When such materials are present, natural contamination (e.g. the radiocarbon reservoir effect, a common issue in this region) can lead to inaccurate and misleading dates. Although several geochronologic techniques have been used to date historic lake level changes in lower Taylor Valley, radiocarbon dating of organic materials has, by far, been the most extensively applied method. Thus, much of what is known regarding the lake level history of the valley is dependent on dating hard to find materials and trusting that those materials are not contaminated, though there is no means to ensure they are not. The need for a different approach that does not depend on organic materials is obvious.

The method used in this project combines surface exposure dating of inorganic materials using in situ 14C cosmogenic radionuclides (in situ 14C) and optically stimulated luminescence dating (OSL) of buried sediments. OSL and in situ 14C do not depend on organic materials, and are therefore promising geochronometers for the recent past in this region. In situ 14C dates indicate the timing of a lake level drop to below the elevation of a dated surface, while OSL dates indicate when a dated depoitional feature was actively being deposited (i.e. when lake levels were at or above the elevation of that deposit). These complementary methods therefore paint a fairly complete, albeit low resolution, record of historic lake level changes.

Initial results from this project suggest historic high lake levels in lower Taylor Valley persisted until 7.25 ka, which is more recent than has been proposed by previous lake level chronologies. This may indicate that ice sheet retreat from the mouth of Taylor Valley following the Last Glacial Maximum occurred more recently than previously thought. In addition, the rate of lake level changes suggested by this research are notably slower than those associated with previous chronologies. These slower rates of change are more in line with modern lake level change rates in the region. 

The initial results also reveal that some alpine glaciers in lower Taylor Valley were much more extensive during the past 24 kyr than previously thought based on  in situ 14C samples collected from glacial morains intersecting high-elevation strandlines. This may have significant implications for the lateral extent of historic high-stand lakes in this part of the valley and for the size of the lake basin that these high lake levels occupied. These results stand in stark contrast with the current understanding of the history of alpine glaciations in the region. 

Intellectual merit: By broadening, and in some cases changing, our understanding of the recent natural history of lower Taylor Valley, this research has opened the door for future paleoclimatic, paleo-hydrologic, and paleoecological studies in lower Taylor Valley and the surrounding region. 

The combination of in situ 14C and OSL has proven an effective method for dating lake level changes and landscape evolution in the region. This research therefore provides a means for reexamining previously proposed chronologies throughout the region, while simultaneously supporting the need for a reexamination of chronological data dealing with the recent past throughout southern Victoria Land. Given the right conditions, the methods used here could also prove useful in developing chronologies in regions beyond Victoria Land where organically derived deposits are rare and/or are subject to natural contamination. 

Broader impacts: The results of this research may have implications for the understanding of ice sheet movement in the region, and certainly alter the understanding of the regional paleoclimatic response to ice sheet advances during the last ice age. Thus, this research highlights potential inefficiencies in paleoclimatic models for Antarctica during the last ice age. A firm understanding of global paleoclimates has been critical in developing climate models to predict the impacts of anthropogenic climate change.
